title: 3D print descriptions
text:
3D printing, or additive manufacturing, is a fabrication method that creates three-dimensional objects by depositing materials layer-by-layer, based on a digital model. Models can be printed in a wide range of materials, including polymers, metals, and ceramics. The process begins with a 3D CAD model, which is then sliced into thin layers. 3D printers follow these slices, building the object from the bottom up. Advantages of 3D printing include rapid prototyping, customizability, and “unorthodox” geometries difficult to obtain by traditional manufacturing methods.
This exhibit showcases 3D printed mass spectrometer parts, custom laboratory equipment, and instructive teaching aids. The designs with their description are available on this website. If using any of these designs in your own work, make sure the material is compatible with the conductivity requirements and environment of the application, including temperature, pressure, and exposure to chemicals or solvents. We hold no responsibility for any harm and/or damage caused by the models on this page.





- - analytical-column-storage-and-transport-box


- - lc-fitting-union-holder


I - thermofisher-scientific-lcms-tool-kit


J - levered-nut-knurl-for-viper-fitting

L - oven-door-v5.stl

Submitted by: Steven Williams


Affiliation: Thermo Fisher Scientific





General description: This box can be used to store or transport analytical columns to prevent damage.


Description of material: Recommend printing in PETG, required no assembly and does not require supports if printed in the orientation with the top of the lid on the build surface. Recommend adding foam inside the box for protecting the column, the foam that column is packaged with can be used.


License: CC-BY














Submitted by: Steven Williams


Affiliation: Children’s Medical Research Institute





General description: A holder to help easily tighten ferrules to LC tubing without having to do it in a port.


Description of material: Printed in PLA, no assembly or finishing required.


License: CC-BY














Submitted by: Steven Williams


Affiliation: Thermo Fisher Scientific





General description: A toolbox for holding common tools for use with ThermoFisher LC and MS instruments. This keeps your tools neat and organised, so you always know where to find them. It holds two hex keys, a fitting torque wrench, two varieties of transfer tube tools, pump seal replacement tool, two viper plugs, a viper union, U3000 needle replacement wrench, several pump piston alignment tools and a syringe seal removal tool.


Description of material: This tool kit can be printed in PLA or PETG and does not require supports or assembly. It is two parts, a body and a lid. To print with Thermo colour theme, print the lid in black before changing to red for the last few layers - this also helps the embossed text stand out.


License: CC-BY














Submitted by: Steven Williams


Affiliation: Thermo Fisher Scientific





General description: A Viper Fitting Nut with a lever arm to easily grip to tighten fittings easily in tight places. Can also be used as a printable replacement part if original nut knurl is lost.


Description of material: Recommend printing in PETG for strenght, no finishing or assembly required.


License: CC-BY














Submitted by: Shane Karnik


Affiliation: Pyxant Labs/ImaBiotech





General description: Evosep_Hamilton_Final.stl This is an adapter for the Evosep tip container. It allows the tip container to be used in the Hamilton STAR/STARLet and Nimbus platforms. It also allows the tip container to fit into any place that a standard 96-well deep-well container will fit, including the centrifuges. While not only does this allow for us to create automated methods, it also provides for a better extraction process, as the centrifugation process is noticeably better when the tip containers are locked into place rather than in a bed that is slightly too large.


Description of material: material: PETG color: black method of printing: FDM finishing: none assembly: none


License: CC-BY











Submitted by: Shane Karnik


Affiliation: Pyxant Labs/ImaBiotech





General description: Oven Door v5.stl This is a replacement door for the Shimadzu oven chamber. The factory doors can be broken fairly easily, and is problematic because there is a sensor that will keep the column from heating up if the door is not closed. This replacement allows us to put a new door on that is compatible with the built-in sensors. It also has a physical latch that bypasses the built-in latch to ensure that even if that latch is not functioning, the door will remain in-place during use.


Description of material: material: PLA color: Grey method of printing: FDM finishing: none assembly: none


License: CC-BY











Submitted by: DAYA RAJU ADYE


Affiliation: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF PHARMACEUTICAL EDUCATION AND RESEARCH, GUWAHATI.





General description: 3D printing has emerged as a novel technology for advanced analytical sample preparation techniques. 3D printing enables the prototyping of devices at a low cost. SPE and LLE 3D printed devices have been made in the last couple of years cost-effectively. These successful applications of the new sample preparation method provide a new strategy for the bioanalysis of compounds from complex biological matrices. Exploring new extraction techniques is a trend in analytical chemistry and biomedicine. In the present study, we fabricated our own indigenous native filament using PVA along with Eudragit® RSPO, pH-independent polymer, and plasticizer TEC using the HME technique to enable a customized filament followed by 3D printed sorbent for the extraction of small molecules. The extracted samples were further analyzed using LC-MS/MS. We successfully extracted hydrocortisone from human plasma using a 3D printed sorbent and analyzed it using a validated LC-MS/MS method. The extraction efficiency was >80%. New cost effective extraction techniques using 3D sorbents are one of the most revolutionary techniques in bioanalytical sciences. Our developed 3D sorbent is a milestone that can aid in the development of analytical extraction techniques.


Description of material: Eudragit® RSPO and PVA were weighed and mixed in a ratio of 1:1 (w/w) with the addition of triethyl citrate (TEC) (8.5 %w/w) as a plasticizer and extruded through a co-rotating twin-screw hot-melt extruder (HAAKE MiniLab II Thermo Scientific, UK) at 60 rpm at a temperature of 120 °C. The average diameter of the extruded filament should be 6.0 cm of extruded length and maintain an acceptable diameter of 2.80 (±0.03) mm for further FDM mediated 3DP, which is in agreement with the diameter of the print-core nozzle, i.e., 2.85 mm.
Computer-aided design (CAD) software SOLIDWORKS (SOLIDWORKS-2019, US) was used to design the prototypes of the 3D sorbent and exported as stereolithography (STL) file. The CAD file dimension of the designed 3D sorbent was 15.0 mm length, 5.0 mm width, 1.5 mm internal cut radius (up to the length), 1.0 mm thickness, and 1.62 mm internal arch used to cut through the thickness. A cylindrical-shaped flake was chosen as the design of the 3D printed sorbent, which made it easy to insert inside the Eppendorf tube. The STL file format contains the desired dimensions of the 3D sorbent needed for the 3D printer slicer software (Ultimaker Cura Version 4.2.1, Singapore) to slice the objects and convert them into a G-code file format. The printing parameters were as follows: layer height, 0.1 mm; in-fill density, 100% (to avoid void formation); infill pattern, triangle; printing temp., 140 C; build-plate temperature, 60 C; printing speed, 70 mm/s; fan speed, 70%; print-core nozzle diameter, 0.4 mm; and total printing time,4min/sorbent. The 3D printed sorbent was printed using a 3D printer (Ultimaker 3, Ultimaker, Germany) using the FDM technology.
The dimensions of the designed cylindrical 3D printed sorbents were 15.0 mm length, 5.0 mm width, 1.5 mm internal cut radius (up to the length), 1.0 mm thickness, and 1.62 mm internal arch (used to cut through the thickness). The cylindrical flake-like geometry provides a larger surface area for better adsorption on a smaller volume space; the small volume space makes it easy to insert the sorbent in a regular Eppendorf tube. As mentioned, the prototype 3D sorbent was cylindrical in shape, slightly yellowish in colour, characteristic odour, non-fragile, and rigid in texture. Surface strandlines were visible at the sorbent surface, which may be due to layer-by-layer extrusion printing.


License: CC-BY

General description: A bead dispenser for use with barocycler tubes and 1 mm lysis beads. Can dispense into anywhere between 1 and 32 tubes simultaneously saving vast amounts of time during sample prep of proteomic samples that use a barocycler.


Description of material: Printed in PLA, no assembly or finishing required.


License: CC-BY














Submitted by: Steven Williams


Affiliation: Thermo Fisher Scientific





General description: Small pipette tip racks that can conveniently transported due to their pocket size. This will allow you to move tips between labs if you are required to work in several locations.


Description of material: Print in PLA, no supports required. You can print the exchangeable tip holders in the colour theme of the tip volume used by the supplying vendor, for example, grey for 10 uL, yellow for 200 uL and blue for 1000 uL. The lid can be attached to the body by placing a M2*8 set nut into the body and using an 8mm M2 screw through the lid. There is also space to insert 2mm diameter x 1mm deep magnets in the lid to help it stay clipped closed but this is not necessary.


License: CC-BY














Submitted by: Shane Karnik


Affiliation: Pyxant Labs/Imabiotech





General description: This is a print created to help users put caps onto their 96-well sample plate. It allows a user to place the plate into a cutout surrounded by guide rails. The user then puts the cap mat on the plate, then uses a rolling pin to firmly press the caps into position. The cutout keeps the plate firmly in place and the rails ensure that the user does not accidentally flip-over their sample plate during the capping process. This makes it faster, safer, and more efficient to cap plates before analysis.


Description of material: Material: PETG Color: black Method of Printing: FDM Finishing: None Assembly: None


License: CC-BY














Submitted by: Shane Karnik


Affiliation: Pyxant Labs/Imabiotech





General description: This is a print that we designed for the Hamilton system. It is specifically for the STAR and STARLet liquid handling systems, and allows users to create bulk QC and STD samples using the automated system. It is designed to hold our, 5mL, 15mL, or 20mL containers and is oriented for convenience. This allows advanced methods to be created and used on our automation hardware.


Description of material: Material: PLA Color: Grey Mehtod of Printing: FDM Finishing: None Assembly: None


License: CC-BY














Submitted by: Shane Karnik


Affiliation: Pyxant Labs/Imabiotech





General description: This print allows the use of 2 standard glassware bottle caps to be put on a single bottle. This can be useful in many situations when a single reagent is to be used for multiple pumps. It provides convenience and streamlining processes in the lab.


Description of material: Material: Polypropylene / CPE Method of Printing: FDM Color: Black (Polypropylene) / Pink (CPE) Finishing: None Assembly: None


License: CC-BY














Submitted by: Mark Osgood


Affiliation: Ashwood Labs





General description: The Ashwood Labs High Voltage Test Fixture 1 is for performing high voltage leakage and breakdown testing. At one end the 3D printed body provides a cavity for potting a high resistor, cable and connector terminations. The completed assembly is designed to slide as a sleeve around then end of a Tektronix P6015A high voltage probe. It safely covers all HV connections and holds the probe in a stable position.


Description of material: Body is Printed in Black PLA with FFF (Fused Filament Fabrication). Breakaway supports used where needed. No post finishing. The completed assembly that this 3D printed body is used in has a connector, an HV resistor and HV leads added. The HV lead terminations are then potted.


License: CC-BY











Submitted by: Mark Larance


Affiliation: The University of Sydney





General description: We aimed to design a 96-well device for use in deep-well centrifuges to increase throughput and consistency when processing StageTips for peptide cleanup, while also minimizing the likelihood of cross-contamination. Our device (Spin96) addresses these issues and was designed with two bottom configurations to allow for a quick changeover between washing and elution steps. Several different plastics for the 3D-printing of Spin96 were tested for durability and usability, with high impact polystyrene (HIPS) chosen for its durability and ease of printing. To optimize the Spin96 protocol, an ideal force of 1000 g was determined as the minimum force required to efficiently pass liquid through StageTips with the Spin96. The protocol for processing SDB-RPS StageTips was also optimized to minimize centrifugation time without compromising the method (see Harney et al. 2019. J Proteome Res. 18(5):2228-2240. DOI: 10.1021/acs.jproteome.9b00090).


Description of material: The Spin96 components were exported as STL files for slicing and printing with a layer height of 0.14 mm. Sliced models were printed using HIPS Natural Black/Gray filament on a Zortrax M200 Plus. Printing on the Zortrax M200 Plus was performed according to the high-quality HIPS profile with either maximum infill (used for the holders, wash-bottom and bottom components), or low infill (used for the top component). Print settings used were: (extruder temperature 255 °C, build-plate temperature 80 °C, chamber temperature 40 °C, fan speed 20%, layer height 0.14 mm, print speed 3600 mm/min, retraction distance 0.5 mm, retraction speed 1800 mm/min, infill percentage 95%, use support with maximum overhang angle of 45° and use raft with 5 mm offset). Each part is printed separately and assembled after removal of supports (see Harney et al. 2019. J Proteome Res. 18(5):2228-2240. DOI: 10.1021/acs.jproteome.9b00090).


License: CC-BY











Submitted by: Kayla Martinez


Affiliation: UTSA





General description: This device was made to serve as a cost-effective gelatin mold to assist in sample preparation of brain homogenate for sulfatide analysis using LC-MS and TIMS-TOF. In addition to having high overall durability and chemical resistance, the mold can withstand temperatures of -80 degrees celsius with no damage to the mold’s structure. The mold’s custom dimensions and overall design make it easy to remove the gelatin without any breakage or tearing.


Description of material: The mold was created using polyethylene terephthalate glycol (PTEG) using UTSA Makerspace’s fused filament fabrication 3D printer. The material comes in various colors, but of the ones available I chose orange. No further assembly is required once the mold has been 3D printed, though it is recommended to ensure that it has no bumps or access material on the surface before using it.


License: CC-BY

General description: Educationnel pieces to leverage the use of whole body animal-tissue imaging as a powefull tools for localizing compounds of biological interest with molecular specificity and high resolution. Applications include pharmaceutical absorptions, distribution, metabolism, excretion studies and biomarker discovery.


Description of material: Material: PLA Color: grey, red, yellow and green method of printing: FDM Finishing: None Assembly: None

Submitted by: Shelly Kalaora


Affiliation: Harvard Medical School





General description: The structure represents a mutated antigen that was identified in cancer patients and presented on the MHC molecule. This peptide induces an immune response in patients and is used today for treating patients. Using mass spectrometry and Immunopeptidomics we purify the peptides presented on MHC to identify tumor antigens, some of them derived from mutations (and called neo-antigens), like this example. These antigens are later used as part of vaccine (as peptides or RNA, like the COVID-19 vaccine) or as cellular immunotherapy (using the T-cells that recognize these antigens), to treat cancer patients that have these mutations.
Link for the file: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/qowxu1yxe62n7u7/AADtbXEimBVTWTrWAm4sS0P6a?dl=0


Description of material: Used PDB structure and ChimeraX to create the 3D printable structure

Submitted by: Luis Schachner

General description: The 3D printed sculpture I wish to display is a stunning representation of the transformation of a mass spectrum into a molecular structure. The sculpture showcases a seamless blend of art and science, bringing together the two disciplines in a visually striking way. As an additional artistic medium, sculpture offers a unique opportunity to explore the three-dimensional nature of scientific data and brings the data to life in a tangible way.
This sculpture has significant utility for science as well. By visually demonstrating the transformation of a mass spectrum into a molecular structure, the sculpture offers a powerful tool for communicating complex scientific concepts. It can help scientists and non-scientists alike to better understand how mass spectrometry works and the insights it can offer into molecular structures. Additionally, the sculpture can be used to demonstrate the potential of 3D printing technology in scientific research and education.
Overall, the 3D printed sculpture represents an exciting opportunity to showcase the intersection of art and science in a way that is both visually captivating and scientifically informative. It has the potential to inspire curiosity and imagination in viewers and to encourage further exploration of the potential of 3D printing technology in scientific research and education.


Description of material: 3D-Printed in nylon and painted with a bronze finish. Please note that STL file will be sent separately to ASMS as the file size is too large.


License: CC-BY

Submitted by: Kevin Zemaitis


Affiliation: Pacific Northwest National Laboratory





General description: The printed source is an inexpensive way to produce reproducible geometries for desorption electrospray ionization (DESI) and more recently low-temperature plasma (LTP) with minimal time and monetary investment. While only these DESI having been demonstrated, and LTP integration in progress, the end user can remix and reuse the ambient source for other purposes. Additionally, any expensive commercial positioners can be replaced with printed or machined solutions for spot profiling analysis, but for imaging, an additional investment is needed for an array of motorized linear stages as described in greater detail elsewhere:
Zemaitis KJ, Izydorczak AM, Thompson AC, Wood TD. Streamlined Multimodal DESI and MALDI Mass Spectrometry Imaging on a Singular Dual-Source FT-ICR Mass Spectrometer. Metabolites. 2021;11(4):253.


Description of material: Printed by fused deposition modeling (FDM) this source was originally created on a consumer grade printer (Creality Ender 3) in PLA. Later versions with subtle modifications to the original design to adapt different linear positioners are now printed in ABS on a Prusa i3 Mk3. The material, layer height, nozzle width, etc. will change based upon the printer used, and the end user needs to optimize for best print quality.
The model uses brass inserts for non-galling threads that are heat set into the printed parts, this forms strong connections and modelled parts are built around commercial accessories (e.g., Bruker Daltonics online nanospray adapter). While a common accessory for certain spectrometers (e.g., FTICR MS), we acknowledge not every instrument (e.g., FTICR, TOF, IT) was equipped with a legacy online nanospray source, however, this can be replaced by a printed solution. Given the heat produced within the Apollo II source block, careful consideration should be completed for material choice. The source mounts directly to the Apollo II source and uses the existing atmospheric pressure ionization inlet with a capillary extension. The source and assembly are described in greater detail elsewhere:
Zemaitis KJ, Wood TD. Integration of 3D-printing for a desorption electrospray ionization source for mass spectrometry. Review of Scientific Instruments. 2020;91(10):104102.


License: CC-BY











Submitted by: Carter Asef


Affiliation: Georgia Institute of Technology





General description: A nanoESI emitter must be held in close proximity to the mass spectrometer inlet with fine control on position and angle. To achieve this capability, our lab designed and printed a cartridge that would firmly hold the nanoESI emitter while being positioned with a ring stand and x, y, z manual linear stage. High temperature resin was used to allow for compatibility with mass spectrometer inlet temperatures exceeding 200 degrees Celsius.
The cartridge prints in a single piece with minimal supports and post processing.


Description of material: Formlabs high temp V2 resin on formlabs form 3 SLA 3d printer. Post processing includes a 6-minute wash in isopropanol followed by 120 minutes in a UV curing station held at 80 degrees Celsius.


License: CC-BY














Submitted by: Hayden Thurman


Affiliation: Wichita State University





General description: 3d printed nESI holder and high resolution FAIMS holder enables IMS on Bruker amaZon. Pictures of full set up in use on front page of my website: www.nexichem.com


Description of material: Black Polyamide carbon fiber printed via high temp FDM (300C). High quality surface finish requires no post processing.


License: CC-BY














Submitted by: Gerard Hopfgartner


Affiliation: University of Geneva





General description: The performance of the devices were investigated for the analysis of solid and liquid samples with electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS). Direct analysis in less than 1 min and without any sample preparation, enabled detection of pesticides (azoxtystrobin/imazalil) on fruits peel surface and illegal substances (MDMA/MDEA) in home-made pills. Conjunction of OPP in the overspill mode with a customized autosampler, equipped with disposable pipette tips, enables direct quantitative analysis of drugs of abuse in urine and plasma, with minimized carry-over and reduced matrix effect compared to flow injection analysis.
DOI: 10.1016/j.talanta.2020.120894 DOI: 10.1039/D2AN00925K


Description of material: Three dimensional printed open port probe (3DP-OPP) and air displacement based liquid handler, were designed and optimized using fused deposition modeling (FDM) and stereolitography (SLA) 3D printing. The performance of the devices were investigated for the analysis of solid and liquid samples with electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS).


License: CC-BY














Submitted by: Magnus Rydberg


Affiliation: Indiana University Purdue University Indianapolis





General description: This device was developed to enable electrokinetic (EK) manipulations (stacking, crude separations, and desalting) on the same paper used to perform paper spray MS. EK stacking improved detection limits 2-3 orders of magnitude with broad analyte compatibility. Online separations and desalting enabled analysis of complex samples with minimal deleterious effects from ion suppression. These improvements were realized without offline sample preparation or the complex instrumentation required to couple HPLC or CE online with MS. To demonstrate the practical utility of the cartridge, per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) were detected quantitatively from tap water with sub-ppt detection limits in less than 10 minutes.


Description of material: The cartridge is printed with a Prusa Mini+ using black Fiberology polypropylene filament. Ultimaker adhesion sheets are used and the print bed is not heated. The nozzle diameter is 0.25mm and the layer height 0.1mm. After the print is done, supports and brim are removed with tweezers and scalpel and the print sonicated in 50/50 water/methanol for 10 minutes. Copper wires are attached at the rear of the bottom section for electrical connections and platinum wires are inserted into the liquid reservoirs. The spray substrate is inserted into the top section and attached to the bottom section.


License: CC-BY














Submitted by: Steven Williams


Affiliation: Children’s Medical Research Institute





General description: This clip can be used to hold down the source activation button on a Sciex Optiflow source, which allows you to use a column set up that does not require the Sciex column holder, which may not suit all applications.


Description of material: Printed in PLA, no assembly or finishing required.

Description of material: Printed in PLA, no assembly or finishing required. Two required.


License: CC-BY














Submitted by: Robert Winkler


Affiliation: CINVESTAV UGA-Langebio Irapuato, Mexico





General description: The 3D-Printed Low-Temperature Plasma (LTP) probe enables the ambient ionization of molecules from solids, liquids, and gases for direct mass spectrometry (MS) and ion mobility spectrometry (IMS) [1,2].
Mounting the 3D-LTP probe on a robotic platform permits the high-throughput screening of spirits and essential oils [3,4]. The special probe design with an inner glass tube reduces the typical hazards of LTP probes (arcing, high temperatures, and ozone generation) and allows the imaging of native biological tissues without sample preparation [5-8]. In addition, the real-time monitoring of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in biological systems, such as studying the biosynthesis of natural products and plant-microbe interactions, is possible [9,10].

Martínez-Jarquín, S.; Moreno-Pedraza, A.; Guillén-Alonso, H.; Winkler, R. Template for 3D Printing a Low-Temperature Plasma Probe. Anal. Chem. 2016, 88 (14), 6976-6980. https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.analchem.6b01019.
Martínez-Jarquín, S.; Winkler, R. Low-Temperature Plasma (LTP) Jets for Mass Spectrometry (MS): Ion Processes, Instrumental Set-Ups, and Application Examples. TrAC Trends in Analytical Chemistry 2017, 89, 133-145. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.trac.2017.01.013.
Rosas-Román, I.; Ovando-Vázquez, C.; Moreno-Pedraza, A.; Guillén-Alonso, H.; Winkler, R. Open LabBot and RmsiGUI: Community Development Kit for Sampling Automation and Ambient Imaging. Microchemical Journal 2020, 152, 104343. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.microc.2019.104343.
Martínez-Jarquín, S.; Moreno-Pedraza, A.; Cázarez-García, D.; Winkler, R. Automated Chemical Fingerprinting of Mexican Spirits Derived from Agave (Tequila and Mezcal) Using Direct-Injection Electrospray Ionisation (DIESI) and Low-Temperature Plasma (LTP) Mass Spectrometry. Anal. Methods 2017, 9 (34), 5023-5028. https://doi.org/10.1039/C7AY00793K.
Martínez‐Jarquín, S.; Winkler, R. Design of a Low‐temperature Plasma (LTP) Probe with Adjustable Output Temperature and Variable Beam Diameter for the Direct Detection of Organic Molecules. Rapid Communications in Mass Spectrometry 2013, 27 (5), 629-634.
García-Rojas, N. S.; Moreno-Pedraza, A.; Rosas-Román, I.; Ramírez-Chávez, E.; Molina-Torres, J.; Winkler, R. Mass Spectrometry Imaging of Thin-Layer Chromatography Plates Using Laser Desorption/Low-Temperature Plasma Ionisation. Analyst 2020, 145 (11), 3885-3891. https://doi.org/10.1039/D0AN00446D.
Moreno-Pedraza, A.; Rosas-Román, I.; Garcia-Rojas, N. S.; Guillén-Alonso, H.; Ovando-Vázquez, C.; Díaz-Ramírez, D.; Cuevas-Contreras, J.; Vergara, F.; Marsch-Martínez, N.; Molina-Torres, J.; Winkler, R. Elucidating the Distribution of Plant Metabolites from Native Tissues with Laser Desorption Low-Temperature Plasma Mass Spectrometry Imaging. Anal. Submitted by: Vilmos Kertesz


Affiliation: Oak Ridge National Laboratory





General description: Attached is a small Openport Sampling Interface (OPSI). Also sending link to examples, including an ESI ion source that was already printed (in hand), the size is 400 um. Utility: surface sampling and demo/educational purpose. Magnification glass/optical microscopy will be provided at the conference. The main idea here is, that generally people know about FDM or UV resin printing, both provides around 100 um RESOLUTION. NanoScribe allows 1 um resolution. We were able to add structures inside fused silica capillaries as well, that will be brought too.


Description of material: Material: IP photoresin Color: transparent Method of printing: Two-Photon Polymerization

title: ProteomicsML
text:
from stl import mesh
from mpl_toolkits import mplot3d
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt

# Create a new plot
figure = pyplot.figure()
axes = mplot3d.Axes3D(figure)

# Load the STL files and add the vectors to the plot
your_mesh = mesh.Mesh.from_file('3D_files/nucleosome.stl')

print(your_mesh)

axes.add_collection3d(mplot3d.art3d.Poly3DCollection(your_mesh.vectors))

# Auto scale to the mesh size
scale = your_mesh.points.flatten()

print(scale)

axes.auto_scale_xyz(scale, scale, scale)

# Show the plot to the screen
plt.show()

import vtk

# Load STL file
reader = vtk.vtkSTLReader()
reader.SetFileName("3D_files/nucleosome.stl")
reader.Update()

# Get output data from reader
stl_data = reader.GetOutput()


# Create mapper
mapper = vtk.vtkPolyDataMapper()
mapper.SetInputData(stl_data)


# Create actor
actor = vtk.vtkActor()
actor.SetMapper(mapper)


# Create renderer
renderer = vtk.vtkRenderer()
renderer.AddActor(actor)
renderer.SetBackground(0.1, 0.2, 0.4) # Set background color

# Create window and add renderer
window = vtk.vtkRenderWindow()
window.AddRenderer(renderer)

# Set window size and show window
window.SetSize(800, 600)
window.Render()
window.SetWindowName("STL Viewer")

# Set interactor and start event loop
interactor = vtk.vtkRenderWindowInteractor()
interactor.SetRenderWindow(window)
interactor.Start()


import vtk

# Load STL file
reader = vtk.vtkSTLReader()
reader.SetFileName("3D_files/nucleosome.stl")
reader.Update()

# Create mapper and actor
mapper = vtk.vtkPolyDataMapper()
mapper.SetInputData(reader.GetOutput())
actor = vtk.vtkActor()
actor.SetMapper(mapper)

# Create renderer and window
renderer = vtk.vtkRenderer()
renderer.AddActor(actor)
renderer.SetBackground(0.1, 0.2, 0.4)
window = vtk.vtkRenderWindow()
window.AddRenderer(renderer)
window.SetSize(800, 600)

# Create window-to-image filter
w2if = vtk.vtkWindowToImageFilter()
w2if.SetInput(window)
w2if.Update()

# Create PNG writer
writer = vtk.vtkPNGWriter()
writer.SetFileName("output.png")
writer.SetInputData(w2if.GetOutput())
writer.Write()


import vtk

# Load STL file
reader = vtk.vtkSTLReader()
reader.SetFileName("3D_files/nucleosome.stl")
reader.Update()

# Create mapper and actor
mapper = vtk.vtkPolyDataMapper()
mapper.SetInputData(reader.GetOutput())
actor = vtk.vtkActor()
actor.SetMapper(mapper)

# Create renderer and window
renderer = vtk.vtkRenderer()
renderer.AddActor(actor)
renderer.SetBackground(0.1, 0.2, 0.4)
window = vtk.vtkRenderWindow()
window.AddRenderer(renderer)
window.SetSize(800, 600)

# Adjust camera position and focal point
camera = renderer.GetActiveCamera()
bounds = actor.GetBounds()
center = [(bounds[0]+bounds[1])/2, (bounds[2]+bounds[3])/2, (bounds[4]+bounds[5])/2]
distance = max(bounds[1]-bounds[0], bounds[3]-bounds[2], bounds[5]-bounds[4])
camera.SetPosition(center[0], center[1], center[2]+1.5*distance)
camera.SetFocalPoint(center[0], center[1], center[2])

# Create window-to-image filter
w2if = vtk.vtkWindowToImageFilter()
w2if.SetInput(window)
w2if.Update()

# Create PNG writer
writer = vtk.vtkPNGWriter()
writer.SetFileName("output.png")
writer.SetInputData(w2if.GetOutput())
writer.Write()


import vtk

# Load STL file
reader = vtk.vtkSTLReader()
reader.SetFileName("3D_files/nucleosome.stl")
reader.Update()

# Create mapper and actor
mapper = vtk.vtkPolyDataMapper()
mapper.SetInputData(reader.GetOutput())
actor = vtk.vtkActor()
actor.SetMapper(mapper)

# Set actor color to red
actor.GetProperty().SetColor(1, 0, 0)

# Create renderer and window
renderer = vtk.vtkRenderer()
renderer.AddActor(actor)
renderer.SetBackground(1, 1, 1) # set background color to white
window = vtk.vtkRenderWindow()
window.AddRenderer(renderer)
window.SetSize(800, 600)

# Adjust camera position and focal point
camera = renderer.GetActiveCamera()
bounds = actor.GetBounds()
center = [(bounds[0]+bounds[1])/2, (bounds[2]+bounds[3])/2, (bounds[4]+bounds[5])/2]
distance = max(bounds[1]-bounds[0], bounds[3]-bounds[2], bounds[5]-bounds[4])
camera.SetPosition(center[0], center[1], center[2]+1.5*distance)
camera.SetFocalPoint(center[0], center[1], center[2])

# Create window-to-image filter
w2if = vtk.vtkWindowToImageFilter()
w2if.SetInput(window)
w2if.Update()

# Create PNG writer
writer = vtk.vtkPNGWriter()
writer.SetFileName("output.png")
writer.SetInputData(w2if.GetOutput())
writer.Write()

title: 3D print descriptions
text:
3D printing, or additive manufacturing, is a fabrication method that creates three-dimensional objects by depositing materials layer-by-layer, based on a digital model. Models can be printed in a wide range of materials, including polymers, metals, and ceramics. The process begins with a 3D CAD model, which is then sliced into thin layers. 3D printers follow these slices, building the object from the bottom up. Advantages of 3D printing include rapid prototyping, customizability, and “unorthodox” geometries difficult to obtain by traditional manufacturing methods.
This exhibit showcases 3D printed mass spectrometer parts, custom laboratory equipment, and instructive teaching aids. The designs with their description are available on this website.
If using any of these designs in your own work, make sure the material is compatible with the conductivity requirements and environment of the application, including temperature, pressure, and exposure to chemicals or solvents. We hold no responsibility for any harm and/or damage caused by the models on this page.





A - printable-framework-for-ambient-ionization-on-commercial-bruker-daltonics-instruments


B - nanoesi-emitter-holder-cartridge


C - custom-nano-esi-holder-and-high-resolution-faims-holder-enables-ims-on-bruker-amazon-ion-trap


D - application-of-3d-printed-tools-for-customized-open-port-probe-electrospray-mass-spectrometry


E - electrokinetic-stacking-cartridge-for-paper-spray-ms


F - button-clip-for-zenotof-optiflow-source


F - optiflow-source-button-clip


G - mass-spec-rail-horse


H - low-temperature-plasma-probe-for-in-vivo-aims-and-msi











Submitted by: Kevin Zemaitis


Affiliation: Pacific Northwest National Laboratory





General description: The printed source is an inexpensive way to produce reproducible geometries for desorption electrospray ionization (DESI) and more recently low-temperature plasma (LTP) with minimal time and monetary investment. While only these DESI having been demonstrated, and LTP integration in progress, the end user can remix and reuse the ambient source for other purposes. Additionally, any expensive commercial positioners can be replaced with printed or machined solutions for spot profiling analysis, but for imaging, an additional investment is needed for an array of motorized linear stages as described in greater detail elsewhere:
Zemaitis KJ, Izydorczak AM, Thompson AC, Wood TD. Streamlined Multimodal DESI and MALDI Mass Spectrometry Imaging on a Singular Dual-Source FT-ICR Mass Spectrometer. Metabolites. 2021;11(4):253.


Printing remarks: Printed by fused deposition modeling (FDM) this source was originally created on a consumer grade printer (Creality Ender 3) in PLA. Later versions with subtle modifications to the original design to adapt different linear positioners are now printed in ABS on a Prusa i3 Mk3. The material, layer height, nozzle width, etc. will change based upon the printer used, and the end user needs to optimize for best print quality.
The model uses brass inserts for non-galling threads that are heat set into the printed parts, this forms strong connections and modelled parts are built around commercial accessories (e.g., Bruker Daltonics online nanospray adapter). While a common accessory for certain spectrometers (e.g., FTICR MS), we acknowledge not every instrument (e.g., FTICR, TOF, IT) was equipped with a legacy online nanospray source, however, this can be replaced by a printed solution. Given the heat produced within the Apollo II source block, careful consideration should be completed for material choice. The source mounts directly to the Apollo II source and uses the existing atmospheric pressure ionization inlet with a capillary extension. The source and assembly are described in greater detail elsewhere:
Zemaitis KJ, Wood TD. Integration of 3D-printing for a desorption electrospray ionization source for mass spectrometry. Review of Scientific Instruments. 2020;91(10):104102.


License: CC-BY











Submitted by: Carter Asef


Affiliation: Georgia Institute of Technology





General description: A nanoESI emitter must be held in close proximity to the mass spectrometer inlet with fine control on position and angle. To achieve this capability, our lab designed and printed a cartridge that would firmly hold the nanoESI emitter while being positioned with a ring stand and x, y, z manual linear stage. High temperature resin was used to allow for compatibility with mass spectrometer inlet temperatures exceeding 200 degrees Celsius.
The cartridge prints in a single piece with minimal supports and post processing.


Printing remarks: Formlabs high temp V2 resin on formlabs form 3 SLA 3d printer. Post processing includes a 6-minute wash in isopropanol followed by 120 minutes in a UV curing station held at 80 degrees Celsius.


License: CC-BY


Download: Download 3D file














Submitted by: Hayden Thurman


Affiliation: Wichita State University





General description: 3d printed nESI holder and high resolution FAIMS holder enables IMS on Bruker amaZon. Pictures of full set up in use on front page of my website: www.nexichem.com


Printing remarks: Black Polyamide carbon fiber printed via high temp FDM (300C). High quality surface finish requires no post processing.


License: CC-BY


Download: Download 3D file














Submitted by: Gerard Hopfgartner


Affiliation: University of Geneva





General description: The performance of the devices were investigated for the analysis of solid and liquid samples with electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS). Direct analysis in less than 1 min and without any sample preparation, enabled detection of pesticides (azoxtystrobin/imazalil) on fruits peel surface and illegal substances (MDMA/MDEA) in home-made pills. Conjunction of OPP in the overspill mode with a customized autosampler, equipped with disposable pipette tips, enables direct quantitative analysis of drugs of abuse in urine and plasma, with minimized carry-over and reduced matrix effect compared to flow injection analysis.
DOI: 10.1016/j.talanta.2020.120894 DOI: 10.1039/D2AN00925K


Printing remarks: Three dimensional printed open port probe (3DP-OPP) and air displacement based liquid handler, were designed and optimized using fused deposition modeling (FDM) and stereolitography (SLA) 3D printing. The performance of the devices were investigated for the analysis of solid and liquid samples with electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS).


License: CC-BY


Download: Download 3D file














Submitted by: Magnus Rydberg


Affiliation: Indiana University Purdue University Indianapolis





General description: This device was developed to enable electrokinetic (EK) manipulations (stacking, crude separations, and desalting) on the same paper used to perform paper spray MS. EK stacking improved detection limits 2-3 orders of magnitude with broad analyte compatibility. Online separations and desalting enabled analysis of complex samples with minimal deleterious effects from ion suppression. These improvements were realized without offline sample preparation or the complex instrumentation required to couple HPLC or CE online with MS. To demonstrate the practical utility of the cartridge, per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) were detected quantitatively from tap water with sub-ppt detection limits in less than 10 minutes.


Printing remarks: The cartridge is printed with a Prusa Mini+ using black Fiberology polypropylene filament. Ultimaker adhesion sheets are used and the print bed is not heated. The nozzle diameter is 0.25mm and the layer height 0.1mm. After the print is done, supports and brim are removed with tweezers and scalpel and the print sonicated in 50/50 water/methanol for 10 minutes. Copper wires are attached at the rear of the bottom section for electrical connections and platinum wires are inserted into the liquid reservoirs. The spray substrate is inserted into the top section and attached to the bottom section.


License: CC-BY

Submitted by: Robert Winkler


Affiliation: CINVESTAV UGA-Langebio Irapuato, Mexico





General description: The 3D-Printed Low-Temperature Plasma (LTP) probe enables the ambient ionization of molecules from solids, liquids, and gases for direct mass spectrometry (MS) and ion mobility spectrometry (IMS) [1,2].
Mounting the 3D-LTP probe on a robotic platform permits the high-throughput screening of spirits and essential oils [3,4]. The special probe design with an inner glass tube reduces the typical hazards of LTP probes (arcing, high temperatures, and ozone generation) and allows the imaging of native biological tissues without sample preparation [5-8]. In addition, the real-time monitoring of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in biological systems, such as studying the biosynthesis of natural products and plant-microbe interactions, is possible [9,10].

Martínez-Jarquín, S.; Moreno-Pedraza, A.; Guillén-Alonso, H.; Winkler, R. Template for 3D Printing a Low-Temperature Plasma Probe. Anal. Chem. 2016, 88 (14), 6976-6980. https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.analchem.6b01019.

Submitted by: Shelly Kalaora


Affiliation: Harvard Medical School





General description: The structure represents a mutated antigen that was identified in cancer patients and presented on the MHC molecule. This peptide induces an immune response in patients and is used today for treating patients. Using mass spectrometry and Immunopeptidomics we purify the peptides presented on MHC to identify tumor antigens, some of them derived from mutations (and called neo-antigens), like this example. These antigens are later used as part of vaccine (as peptides or RNA, like the COVID-19 vaccine) or as cellular immunotherapy (using the T-cells that recognize these antigens), to treat cancer patients that have these mutations.
Link for the file: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/qowxu1yxe62n7u7/AADtbXEimBVTWTrWAm4sS0P6a?dl=0

Submitted by: Luis Schachner

General description: The 3D printed sculpture I wish to display is a stunning representation of the transformation of a mass spectrum into a molecular structure. The sculpture showcases a seamless blend of art and science, bringing together the two disciplines in a visually striking way. As an additional artistic medium, sculpture offers a unique opportunity to explore the three-dimensional nature of scientific data and brings the data to life in a tangible way.
This sculpture has significant utility for science as well. By visually demonstrating the transformation of a mass spectrum into a molecular structure, the sculpture offers a powerful tool for communicating complex scientific concepts. It can help scientists and non-scientists alike to better understand how mass spectrometry works and the insights it can offer into molecular structures. Additionally, the sculpture can be used to demonstrate the potential of 3D printing technology in scientific research and education.
Overall, the 3D printed sculpture represents an exciting opportunity to showcase the intersection of art and science in a way that is both visually captivating and scientifically informative. It has the potential to inspire curiosity and imagination in viewers and to encourage further exploration of the potential of 3D printing technology in scientific research and education.


Printing remarks: 3D-Printed in nylon and painted with a bronze finish. Please note that STL file will be sent separately to ASMS as the file size is too large.

General description: A toolbox for holding common tools for use with ThermoFisher LC and MS instruments. This keeps your tools neat and organised, so you always know where to find them. It holds two hex keys, a fitting torque wrench, two varieties of transfer tube tools, pump seal replacement tool, two viper plugs, a viper union, U3000 needle replacement wrench, several pump piston alignment tools and a syringe seal removal tool.


Printing remarks: This tool kit can be printed in PLA or PETG and does not require supports or assembly. It is two parts, a body and a lid. To print with Thermo colour theme, print the lid in black before changing to red for the last few layers - this also helps the embossed text stand out.

General description: Evosep_Hamilton_Final.stl This is an adapter for the Evosep tip container. It allows the tip container to be used in the Hamilton STAR/STARLet and Nimbus platforms. It also allows the tip container to fit into any place that a standard 96-well deep-well container will fit, including the centrifuges. While not only does this allow for us to create automated methods, it also provides for a better extraction process, as the centrifugation process is noticeably better when the tip containers are locked into place rather than in a bed that is slightly too large.


Printing remarks: material: PETG color: black method of printing: FDM finishing: none assembly: none

Submitted by: Shane Karnik


Affiliation: Pyxant Labs/ImaBiotech





General description: Oven Door v5.stl This is a replacement door for the Shimadzu oven chamber. The factory doors can be broken fairly easily, and is problematic because there is a sensor that will keep the column from heating up if the door is not closed. This replacement allows us to put a new door on that is compatible with the built-in sensors. It also has a physical latch that bypasses the built-in latch to ensure that even if that latch is not functioning, the door will remain in-place during use.


Printing remarks: material: PLA color: Grey method of printing: FDM finishing: none assembly: none

General description: This is a print created to help users put caps onto their 96-well sample plate. It allows a user to place the plate into a cutout surrounded by guide rails. The user then puts the cap mat on the plate, then uses a rolling pin to firmly press the caps into position. The cutout keeps the plate firmly in place and the rails ensure that the user does not accidentally flip-over their sample plate during the capping process. This makes it faster, safer, and more efficient to cap plates before analysis.


Printing remarks: Material: PETG Color: black Method of Printing: FDM Finishing: None Assembly: None

General description: The Ashwood Labs High Voltage Test Fixture 1 is for performing high voltage leakage and breakdown testing. At one end the 3D printed body provides a cavity for potting a high resistor, cable and connector terminations. The completed assembly is designed to slide as a sleeve around then end of a Tektronix P6015A high voltage probe. It safely covers all HV connections and holds the probe in a stable position.


Printing remarks: Body is Printed in Black PLA with FFF (Fused Filament Fabrication). Breakaway supports used where needed. No post finishing. The completed assembly that this 3D printed body is used in has a connector, an HV resistor and HV leads added. The HV lead terminations are then potted.


License: CC-BY











Submitted by: Mark Larance


Affiliation: The University of Sydney





General description: We aimed to design a 96-well device for use in deep-well centrifuges to increase throughput and consistency when processing StageTips for peptide cleanup, while also minimizing the likelihood of cross-contamination. Our device (Spin96) addresses these issues and was designed with two bottom configurations to allow for a quick changeover between washing and elution steps. Several different plastics for the 3D-printing of Spin96 were tested for durability and usability, with high impact polystyrene (HIPS) chosen for its durability and ease of printing. To optimize the Spin96 protocol, an ideal force of 1000 g was determined as the minimum force required to efficiently pass liquid through StageTips with the Spin96. The protocol for processing SDB-RPS StageTips was also optimized to minimize centrifugation time without compromising the method (see Harney et al. 2019. J Proteome Res. 18(5):2228-2240. DOI: 10.1021/acs.jproteome.9b00090).


Printing remarks: The Spin96 components were exported as STL files for slicing and printing with a layer height of 0.14 mm. Sliced models were printed using HIPS Natural Black/Gray filament on a Zortrax M200 Plus. Printing on the Zortrax M200 Plus was performed according to the high-quality HIPS profile with either maximum infill (used for the holders, wash-bottom and bottom components), or low infill (used for the top component). Print settings used were: (extruder temperature 255 °C, build-plate temperature 80 °C, chamber temperature 40 °C, fan speed 20%, layer height 0.14 mm, print speed 3600 mm/min, retraction distance 0.5 mm, retraction speed 1800 mm/min, infill percentage 95%, use support with maximum overhang angle of 45° and use raft with 5 mm offset). Each part is printed separately and assembled after removal of supports (see Harney et al. 2019. J Proteome Res. 18(5):2228-2240. DOI: 10.1021/acs.jproteome.9b00090).


License: CC-BY

Submitted by: Kayla Martinez


Affiliation: UTSA





General description: This device was made to serve as a cost-effective gelatin mold to assist in sample preparation of brain homogenate for sulfatide analysis using LC-MS and TIMS-TOF. In addition to having high overall durability and chemical resistance, the mold can withstand temperatures of -80 degrees celsius with no damage to the mold’s structure. The mold’s custom dimensions and overall design make it easy to remove the gelatin without any breakage or tearing.


Printing remarks: The mold was created using polyethylene terephthalate glycol (PTEG) using UTSA Makerspace’s fused filament fabrication 3D printer. The material comes in various colors, but of the ones available I chose orange. No further assembly is required once the mold has been 3D printed, though it is recommended to ensure that it has no bumps or access material on the surface before using it.


License: CC-BY
